articles.headline: Ex-SAC Trader Was Expelled From Harvard Law School
articles.snippet: Mathew Martoma, the former SAC Capital Advisors trader charged with carrying out one of the largest insider trading schemes ever, was expelled from Harvard Law School more than a decade ago for creating a false transcript of his grades, newly unse...
articles.abstract: Mathew Martoma, the former SAC Capital Advisors trader charged with carrying out one of the largest insider trading schemes ever, was expelled from Harvard Law School more than a decade ago for creating a false transcript of his grades, newly unsealed court documents show.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal jury will decide whether Mathew Martoma, the former hedge fund manager, cheated when he worked at SAC Capital Advisors, but there’s no denying he cheated when he falsified his grades at Harvard Law School some 15 years ago.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: JPMorgan Lost Madoff in a Blizzard of Paper
articles.snippet: Documents released in connection with the federal penalties imposed on JPMorgan Chase showed that many people simply filled out and filed forms, oblivious to what they might indicate.
articles.abstract: Documents released in connection with the federal penalties imposed on JPMorgan Chase showed that many people simply filled out and filed forms, oblivious to what they might indicate.
articles.lead_paragraph: Did JPMorgan Chase deliberately cover up Bernard L. Madoff’s fraud?

articles.headline: Even as Wages Rise, China Exports Grow
articles.snippet: China’s export machine has continued to run even as blue-collar wages have soared between fivefold and ninefold in dollar terms in the last decade.
articles.abstract: China’s export machine has continued to run even as blue-collar wages have soared between fivefold and ninefold in dollar terms in the last decade.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Cheng Chunmeng, the general manager of a manufacturer of colorful children’s chairs in east-central China, gave his workers a 30 percent raise last year to keep them from leaving. His labor costs are rising even faster in dollar terms, as the Chinese currency slowly climbs against the United States dollar.

articles.headline: Japanese Begin to Question Protections Given to Homegrown Rice
articles.snippet: A pending free-trade agreement — and at least one Japanese farmer — is posing challenges to the elaborate system that protects the homegrown crop.
articles.abstract: A pending free-trade agreement — and at least one Japanese farmer — is posing challenges to the elaborate system that protects the homegrown crop.
articles.lead_paragraph: AGA, Japan — For decades, Japan has defended its 778 percent tariffs on rice with a kind of religious zeal. Rice is a sacred crop, the government has argued, not open to trade negotiations. Its farmers are not just defenders of a proud agrarian heritage, but form the nation’s spiritual center as well.

articles.headline: More U.S. Economists See Half-Full Glass
articles.snippet: A smaller trade deficit, increased consumer spending and a surging stock market contributed to a revised outlook for United States growth.
articles.abstract: A smaller trade deficit, increased consumer spending and a surging stock market contributed to a revised outlook for United States growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: Record exports and the smallest trade deficit in four years. Healthier consumer spending, including the strongest annual increase in automobile sales since 2007, spurred by a booming stock market and an improving housing sector. And a slow but steady pickup in job creation that has pushed unemployment to its lowest level since 2008.

articles.headline: Awards Shows Help Clark Productions Bounce Back
articles.snippet: Networks these days are craving event television, and, increasingly, Dick Clark Productions’s live, star-studded spectacles are delivering it.
articles.abstract: Networks these days are craving event television, and, increasingly, Dick Clark Productions’s live, star-studded spectacles are delivering it.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — For decades, Dick Clark Productions trundled along on television’s periphery, making a living by reheating chestnuts like “New Year’s Rockin’ Eve” and the American Music Awards.

articles.headline: Syria Militants Said to Recruit Visiting Americans to Attack U.S.
articles.snippet: American intelligence and counterterrorism officials said Islamic extremist groups were trying to identify, recruit and train Westerners to carry out attacks when they returned home.
articles.abstract: American intelligence and counterterrorism officials said Islamic extremist groups were trying to identify, recruit and train Westerners to carry out attacks when they returned home.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Islamic extremist groups in Syria with ties to Al Qaeda are trying to identify, recruit and train Americans and other Westerners who have traveled there to get them to carry out attacks when they return home, according to senior American intelligence and counterterrorism officials.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Falluja’s Fall Stuns Marines Who Fought There
articles.snippet: The bloody mission to wrest Falluja from insurgents in November 2004 meant more to the Marines than almost any other battle in the 12 years of war in Iraq and Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: The bloody mission to wrest Falluja from insurgents in November 2004 meant more to the Marines than almost any other battle in the 12 years of war in Iraq and Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: Adam Banotai was a 21-year-old sergeant and squad leader in the Marine Corps during the 2004 invasion of Falluja, a restive insurgent-held city in Iraq. His unit — which had seven of 17 men wounded by shrapnel or bullets in the first days of the invasion — seized control of the government center early in the campaign.

articles.headline: Wall Street Predicts $50 Billion Bill to Settle U.S. Mortgage Suits
articles.snippet: Using an analysis based on a settlement paid in the residential mortgage crisis by JPMorgan Chase, the banking industry calculated what the rest of the banks might pay.
articles.abstract: Using an analysis based on a settlement paid in the residential mortgage crisis by JPMorgan Chase, the banking industry calculated what the rest of the banks might pay.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street could pay nearly $50 billion to buy peace from federal authorities who are taking aim at the banks over their role in the mortgage crisis, according to interviews and a confidential analysis of the industry’s potential legal exposure.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: As Indian Diplomat Exits After Arrest, a Culture Clash Lingers
articles.snippet: Devyani Khobragade’s return to India represented a possible resolution of a case that has harmed the United States’ ties with New Delhi.
articles.abstract: Devyani Khobragade’s return to India represented a possible resolution of a case that has harmed the United States’ ties with New Delhi.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Two dozen revved-up television crews were clustered outside a V.I.P. exit at Indira Gandhi International Airport on Friday, waiting for the flight from New York. They had been in place for two hours, and every time a trickle of passengers came into view, they all jumped up and pressed their cameras against the glass.
articles.byline: By Ellen Barry and Benjamin Weiser

articles.headline: Growth in Jobs Slows Sharply to 3-Year Low
articles.snippet: In December, employers added just 74,000 jobs, the slowest pace of growth in three years and far below the expectations of many economists who had grown convinced that the market was on a more solid footing.
articles.abstract: In December, employers added just 74,000 jobs, the slowest pace of growth in three years and far below the expectations of many economists who had grown convinced that the market was on a more solid footing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just when it seemed as if the economy was finally accelerating, the latest employment figures once again confounded expectations of better days ahead.

articles.headline: For Target, the Breach Numbers Grow
articles.snippet: The retailer disclosed that the hackers stole a broader trove of data than originally reported, including mailing and email addresses, phone numbers and names.
articles.abstract: The retailer disclosed that the hackers stole a broader trove of data than originally reported, including mailing and email addresses, phone numbers and names.
articles.lead_paragraph: Target on Friday revised the number of customers whose personal information was stolen in a widespread data breach during the holiday season, now reporting a range of 70 million to 110 million people.
articles.byline: By Elizabeth A. Harris and Nicole Perlroth
